questions.text: A 37-year-old primigravid woman at 36 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital 30 minutes after the onset of labor. On arrival, contractions occur every 8–10 minutes. During the last two days, she has noted decreased fetal movements. The pregnancy had been complicated by gestational hypertension. Current medications include labetalol and a pregnancy multivitamin. Her temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 94/min, and blood pressure is 154/96 mm Hg. On pelvic examination, the cervix is 40% effaced and 2 cm dilated; the vertex is at -2 station. The uterus is consistent in size with a 30-week gestation. Ultrasonography shows the fetus in vertex position and a decreased amount of amniotic fluid. A fetal heart tracing is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Umbilical cord prolapse causes a sudden change from a normal CTG trace to either prolonged fetal bradycardia (< 110/min) or recurrent variable decelerations. The change usually occurs after the rupture of membranes, especially in patients with polyhydramnios, when the sudden gush of amniotic fluid can cause the cord to prolapse. However, late decelerations and oligohydramnios are not typical of umbilical cord prolapse.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm), with a baseline of approx. 136 bpm (dashed green line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (∼ 10 bpm; normal range 6–25/minute). The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg).

The three decelerations visible are abrupt, with < 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay), and vary in their shape and their temporal relation to the uterine contractions (dashed red line overlay). These findings are characteristic of variable decelerations. As the decelerations here occur with ≥ 50% of uterine contractions over a 20-minute time period, they are termed “recurrent variable decelerations.” This pattern is concerning for umbilical cord compression/prolapse. If persistent, it may prompt considering emergency cesarean delivery.

B) INCORRECT:

Umbilical cord compression is more common in women with oligohydramnios because of the lack of an amniotic fluid cushion to protect the umbilical cord from being compressed between the fetus and the contracting uterus. However, umbilical cord compression causes recurrent variable decelerations (i.e., decelerations that vary in onset, depth, and duration, and that occur independently of uterine contractions), whereas this patient's CTG is characteristic of late decelerations.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm), with a baseline of approx. 136 bpm (dashed green line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (∼ 10 bpm; normal range 6–25/minute). The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg).

The three decelerations visible are abrupt, with < 30 s from onset to nadir (red arrow overlay), and vary in their shape and their temporal relation to the uterine contractions (dashed red line overlay). These findings are characteristic of variable decelerations. As the decelerations here occur with ≥ 50% of uterine contractions over a 20-minute time period, they are termed “recurrent variable decelerations.” This pattern is concerning for umbilical cord compression/prolapse. If persistent, it may prompt considering emergency cesarean delivery.

C) INCORRECT:

Physiological fetal heart rate (FHR) pattern includes a baseline FHR from 110–160/min, with a variability of 6–25/min (baseline variability), accelerations (associated with fetal movements and autonomic responses), and early decelerations (caused by fetal head compression during normal vaginal delivery). The CTG trace in this patient shows late decelerations, which are indicative of fetal hypoxia and metabolic acidosis.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm) with a baseline of approx. 135 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (~10 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm).
The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg). The black markings above this tracing show fetal movements (blue shading overlay).
There are three FHR accelerations (green arrow overlay), which coincide with periods of increased fetal movement.

D) INCORRECT:

Compression of the fetal head with each uterine contraction as it descends through the birth canal triggers an autonomic response that decreases the fetal heart rate. This mirrors the uterine contractions and is termed early decelerations. Early decelerations are a benign finding and not a sign of nonreassuring fetal status. However, the CTG trace in this patient shows late decelerations, which are indicative of fetal hypoxia and metabolic acidosis.
Image Description:

The upper blue tracing shows the fetal heart rate (FHR) in beats per minute (bpm) with a baseline of approx. 130 bpm (green dashed line overlay). The FHR baseline lies within the normal range (green shading overlay) and shows moderate variability (~10 bpm; normal range 6–25 bpm).
The lower blue tracing shows the maternal uterine contractions (in mm Hg). The black markings above this tracing show fetal movements (blue shading overlay).
Contractions and decelerations begin and end together (red dashed line overlay), with the peaks of the contractions coinciding with the nadirs of the decelerations (red arrow overlay). The decelerations are gradual, with ≥ 30 s from onset to nadir. These findings are characteristic of early decelerations.

E) CORRECT:

Placental insufficiency causes oligohydramnios and intrauterine growth restriction. Because the fetoplacental reserve is decreased in placental insufficiency, stressors, such as labor, can cause fetal hypoxia and metabolic acidosis, which are seen as late decelerations, as in this patient. Gestational hypertension is a common cause of uteroplacental insufficiency. Late decelerations are a sign of fetal distress and should be managed with intrauterine resuscitation and immediate delivery of the fetus.

F) INCORRECT:

This patient presents in the first stage of labor as evidenced by the onset of labor pains 30 minutes earlier and cervical dilation of 2 cm. To diagnose an arrest of active phase of labor, the membranes should already be ruptured and the cervix already dilated to ≥ 6 cm. Moreover, the first stage of labor lasts, on average, for 8–12 hours (longer in primigravid women). This patient currently has normal progression of labor.

G) INCORRECT:

Chorioamnionitis manifests with maternal fever, uterine tenderness, fetal tachycardia, purulent and/or foulsmelling amniotic fluid, and maternal leukocytosis. It is usually associated with premature rupture of membranes and protracted labor. Moreover, a CTG in chorioamnionitis typically shows fetal tachycardia (> 160/min), but not late decelerations.
questions.hint: The onset, nadir, and recovery of the decelerations seen in the fetal heart tracing occur after the onset, peak, and end of the uterine contraction. This finding is characteristic of late decelerations.

questions.text: A 36-year-old primigravid woman at 22 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for a routine prenatal visit. Her previous prenatal visits showed no abnormalities. She has hyperthyroidism treated with methimazole. She smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 15 years but quit 6 years ago. She reports gaining weight after quitting smoking, after which she developed her own weight loss program. She is 168 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 51.2 kg (112.9 lb); BMI is 18 kg/m2. Her temperature is 37°C (98.5°F), pulse is 88/min, and blood pressure is 115/72 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows no abnormalities. The fundus is palpated between the symphysis and the umbilicus. Ultrasound shows a fetal head at the 20th percentile and the abdomen at the 9th percentile. Fetal birth weight is estimated at the 9th percentile and a decreased amniotic fluid index is noted. The maternal quadruple screening test was normal. Thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) is 0.3 μU/mL and free T4 is 1.5 ng/dL. Which of the following is the strongest predisposing factor for the ultrasound findings in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pregnant patients with a history of or current anorexia nervosa are at an increased risk for IUGR due to chronic malnutrition and low pregnancy weight. This risk persists even years after treatment for an eating disorder, most likely due to residual symptoms. Asymmetric intrauterine growth restriction typically occurs in the late 2nd or early 3rd trimester, affecting fetal growth rather than organ formation. Typically, the dimensions of the head are normal due to shunting of blood to vital fetal organs (e.g., brain, heart) while less vital organs (e.g., liver, muscle) are bypassed, resulting in a small trunk and extremities.

B) INCORRECT:

There is little evidence to suggest that advanced maternal age (35–40 years of age) alone is an increased risk factor for IUGR. Instead, advanced maternal age should be considered in the context of other risk factors (e.g., hypertension, diabetes).

C) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine infection with cytomegalovirus or other pathogens that cause TORCH infections can cause fetal growth restriction. However, intrauterine infection causes symmetric IUGR rather than the asymmetric IUGR seen on this ultrasound.

D) INCORRECT:

Fetal aneuploidy is a potential cause of symmetric rather than asymmetric IUGR. Furthermore, this patient's maternal quadruple screening test was normal, making fetal aneuploidy unlikely.

E) INCORRECT:

Current smoking is a significant risk factor for IUGR, likely because of the placental abnormalities that smoking induces. This patient, however, stopped smoking 6 years ago, meaning that nicotine use does not explain the findings.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with overt hyperthyroidism (low TSH and increased free T4 levels) are at increased risk of IUGR and low birth weight. Although this patient's TSH is slightly below normal, her free T4 levels are normal, suggesting subclinical hyperthyroidism, which is not associated with adverse pregnancy outcomes.
questions.hint: Ultrasound findings show disproportional head and abdominal growth, low estimated birth weight (< 10th percentile), and oligohydramnios (decreased amniotic fluid index), all of which suggests asymmetrical intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

questions.text: A 38-year-old primigravid woman at 33 weeks' gestation comes to the office for a prenatal visit. She feels well and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has completed all previous routine prenatal visits. Medical history is remarkable for pregestational hypertension. Her medications are methyldopa, low-dose aspirin, and a prenatal multivitamin. She smoked 5 cigarettes daily for 15 years but stopped when she found out she was pregnant. Her temperature is 36.7°C (98°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 146/94 mm Hg. Physical examination shows a fundal height of 27 cm. Fetal heart rate is 145/min. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Betamethasone therapy and induction of labor

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cell-free fetal DNA testing can be used for prenatal assessment of fetal genetic abnormalities, which are commonly associated with IUGR. Although IUGR is suspected in this patient, the diagnosis needs to be confirmed before the evaluation of potential causes.

B) CORRECT:

In pregnant women with suspected IUGR, transabdominal or transvaginal fetal ultrasonography is indicated for an accurate assessment of pregnancy dating and fetal abnormalities. The diagnosis of IUGR is confirmed by an estimated fetal weight or a fetal abdominal circumference below the 10th percentile. Chronic hypertension, which this patient has, is a risk factor for IUGR because it can lead to placental insufficiency, with a consequent decrease in blood flow and oxygen delivery to the fetus. Other risk factors for this condition include maternal substance abuse (e.g., alcohol, cocaine), teratogen exposure (e.g., carbamazepine, warfarin), multiple gestations, placenta previa, fetal genetic abnormalities, and intrauterine infections. Management includes treatment of the underlying cause (e.g., blood pressure control in this patient) and outpatient monitoring.

C) INCORRECT:

A glucose challenge test should be performed in all pregnant women between 24 and 28 weeks' gestation as part of the screening for gestational diabetes mellitus, which is a risk factor for IUGR. Since this patient is at 33 weeks' gestation and has attended all previous prenatal visits, a glucose challenge test has most likely already been performed. A different step is indicated at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

A contraction stress test can be used for fetal evaluation in patients with severe or complicated IUGR (e.g., fetal weight < 5th percentile, oligohydramnios, preeclampsia, decelerating growth velocity, increasing umbilical Doppler index) and a nonreactive nonstress test. Although IUGR is suspected in this patient, the diagnosis needs to be confirmed before a contraction stress test is considered.

E) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up in 2 weeks would be indicated if this patient's examination showed no abnormalities. However, the discrepancy between fundal height and gestational age suggests IUGR, which requires further evaluation.

F) INCORRECT:

Betamethasone therapy and induction of labor are indicated in patients at < 34 weeks' gestation if preterm delivery, for which IUGR is a risk factor, is anticipated. Although IUGR is suspected in this patient, the diagnosis needs to be confirmed first. In addition, there are no signs of, or indications for, preterm labor at this time.
questions.hint: Between 24 and 36 weeks' gestation, the fundal height (in cm) should roughly equal the gestational age (in weeks). A fundal height of at least 3 cm less than the gestational age, as seen here, should raise concern for intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

questions.text:
A 32-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman presents for a routine early third-trimester prenatal visit. Her pregnancy is complicated by gestational diabetes and gestational hypertension.
She has been treated with medical nutrition therapy and has achieved fasting glucose levels that range from 90 mg/dL to 94 mg/dL and that, 2 hours postprandially, range from 110 mg/dL to 120 mg/dL. Her systolic blood pressure has declined from pretreatment values of 162–168 mm Hg to an average value of 142 mm Hg with labetalol 200 mg twice daily.
She does not have proteinuria.
Which one of the following fetal ultrasonography findings is this woman most likely to have?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Gestational diabetes, especially if poorly controlled, can cause fetal complications, including macrosomia, fetal hydrops, preeclampsia, polyhydramnios, still birth, electrolyte abnormalities, and cardiomyopathy. However, patients whose glucose levels are on target (as in this case) have a very low risk of developing the diabetes-related complications listed above.

B) INCORRECT:

Fetal hepatomegaly has not been associated with either gestational diabetes or gestational hypertension.

C) INCORRECT:

Gestational diabetes, especially if poorly controlled, can cause fetal complications, including macrosomia, fetal hydrops, preeclampsia, polyhydramnios, still birth, electrolyte abnormalities, and cardiomyopathy. However, patients whose glucose levels are on target (as in this case) have a very low risk of developing the diabetes-related complications listed above.

D) INCORRECT:

Gestational diabetes, especially if poorly controlled, can cause fetal complications, including macrosomia, fetal hydrops, preeclampsia, polyhydramnios, still birth, electrolyte abnormalities, and cardiomyopathy. However, patients whose glucose levels are on target (as in this case) have a very low risk of developing the diabetes-related complications listed above.

E) CORRECT:

Gestational hypertension refers to arterial hypertension that develops in a pregnant woman after 20 weeks’ gestation without the presence of protein in the urine. Hypertensive disorders of pregnancy may cause maternal and fetal morbidity, and they remain a leading cause of maternal mortality.

Severe gestational hypertension, defined as systolic blood pressure ≥160 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≥110 mm Hg, as documented in this patient before treatment, is associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) and preterm labor. IUGR is commonly defined as fetal weight below the 10th percentile for gestational age. In one study, the incidence of IUGR in women with a history of severe gestational hypertension was 20.8%, compared with 6.5% in women with a history of nonsevere gestational hypertension and 4.8% in normotensive women. The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends 140/90 mm Hg as the threshold for starting or titrating treatment for chronic hypertension in pregnancy because this threshold results in better outcomes than the previously recommended threshold of 160/110 mm Hg. Although this patient’s risk for IUGR is reduced by treatment, it remains elevated compared to women with nonhypertensive pregnancies.

Gestational diabetes, especially if poorly controlled, can cause fetal complications, including macrosomia, fetal hydrops, preeclampsia, polyhydramnios, still birth, electrolyte abnormalities, and cardiomyopathy. The rate of complications is related to the degree of blood glucose control. For women with gestational diabetes, the American Diabetes Association and the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommend the following target blood glucose levels:

• Fasting: ≤95 mg/dL
• One hour postprandial: ≤140 mg/dL
• Two hours postprandial: ≤120 mg/dL

Patients whose glucose levels are on target (as in this case) have a very low risk of developing the diabetes-related complications listed above.

Key learning point: The most common finding on fetal growth ultrasonography in a pregnant woman with poorly controlled hypertension is intrauterine growth restriction.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old gravida 2, para 1 woman at 25 weeks' gestation by certain last menstrual period and first-trimester ultrasound has a fundal height of 21 cm at routine prenatal visit. She is doing well and reports appropriate fetal movements. The fetal heart rate is reassuring.
A repeat ultrasound reveals normal fetal anatomy and an estimated fetal weight at the 9th percentile. Doppler velocimetry of the umbilical artery reveals normal flow.
In addition to monitoring with periodic ultrasonography and a biophysical profile, what is the most appropriate care plan for this patient?

choices.text: Initiate amnioinfusion until the amniotic fluid index is at the 50th percentile
Recommend bed rest, and initiate low-molecular-weight heparin

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Indomethacin has no role in the treatment of FGR. Indomethacin is a nonsteroidal antiinflammatory drug that is commonly employed to manage preterm labor before 34 weeks, polyhydramnios, and pain from necrosing fibroids.

B) INCORRECT:

Amnioinfusion, a therapy for intrapartum management of oligohydramnios, is neither indicated nor appropriate for a pregnancy with intrauterine FGR.

C) CORRECT:

The ultrasound in this case shows fetal growth restriction (FGR), which is defined as a fetal weight or abdominal circumference below the 10th percentile for gestational age. FGR can be caused by fetal, placental, or maternal factors and should be further evaluated with Doppler blood flow studies of the umbilical artery, as was done in this case. When baseline studies are normal, the recommendation is to repeat ultrasound, biophysical profile, and Doppler velocimetry at regular intervals as determined by the level of clinical concern. Monitoring with Doppler velocimetry, in particular, has been shown to be associated with improved outcomes in FGR, as any deterioration observed can prompt timely interventions that reduce perinatal mortality. Such interventions include early delivery, administration of maternal glucocorticoids, and more-intensive surveillance.

Key learning point: In addition to serial ultrasonography and a biophysical profile, the recommended monitoring test for a pregnancy with fetal growth restriction before the third trimester is Doppler velocimetry.

D) INCORRECT:

Progesterone has no role in the treatment of FGR. Progesterone supplementation has been used to support pregnancies in women who have a history of recurrent pregnancy loss until placental progesterone is sufficient at about 9 to 12 weeks. Weekly intramuscular 17-hydroxyprogesterone has been shown to help reduce the risk of preterm labor.

E) INCORRECT:

Bed rest offers no advantage in the treatment of FGR and increases a patient’s risk for thromboembolic events.

Heparin has no role in the treatment of FGR. Heparin is used as anticoagulation therapy, most commonly in cases of thrombophilia in pregnancy.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old primigravida woman who is at 34 weeks' gestation, according to last menstrual period and first-trimester ultrasound, is seen for a routine prenatal visit. She and the baby’s father both have constitutional short stature.
Her fundal height measures 30 cm. An ultrasound is performed to estimate fetal weight by fetal abdominal circumference; it demonstrates a normal fetal anatomic survey and normal amniotic fluid index but places the fetal weight below the 10th percentile for gestational age.
Which one of the following next steps is most appropriate in this patient's evaluation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although three-dimensional ultrasonography is being studied for assessment of pregnancies complicated by fetal growth restriction, it is not widely available and has not been well studied in large or controlled studies.

B) INCORRECT:

Nonstress testing would be performed to assess for risk of fetal acidemia; it reveals nothing about fetal growth.

C) INCORRECT:

Amniocentesis for fetal karyotype testing would diagnose aneuploidy, which can cause fetal growth restriction. However, this diagnosis would be more likely in a fetus with structural abnormalities such as increased nuchal translucency, echogenic bowel, or an echogenic intracardiac focus.

D) CORRECT:

Umbilical artery Doppler flow velocimetry is useful to differentiate between a fetus that is constitutionally small but healthy and one that has pathological growth restriction and is at risk for perinatal complications. This test can guide the timing of interventions that reduce perinatal mortality, such as early delivery, administration of maternal glucocorticoids, and more-intensive surveillance.

Key learning point: For a fetus with ultrasonographic evidence of either weight or abdominal circumference below the 10th percentile for gestational age, the most effective test to differentiate fetal growth restriction from constitutional small size is umbilical artery Doppler flow velocimetry.

E) INCORRECT:

Interval growth assessment should be at least 3 to 4 weeks apart, not 2 weeks apart.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 woman at 30 weeks’ gestation presents to the Outpatient Clinic for routine prenatal care. She has noticed decreased fetal movements. She smokes occasionally but has no other significant history. Her fundal height is 3 cm smaller than expected. Fetal heart tones are reactive (see report).

Blood pressure
110/72 mm Hg

Ultrasound: Fetus below the 10th percentile for gestational age; amniotic fluid level at the low end of normal
What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Perform a single nonstress test and defer repeat sonography until 36 weeks
Schedule serial ultrasound assessments to monitor fetal growth and Doppler flow

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immediate cesarean delivery at 30 weeks is not warranted without evidence of acute fetal distress or maternal instability. Reactive fetal heart tones and stable ultrasound findings suggest the fetus is not in immediate danger. Continued surveillance and evaluation are appropriate in this context.

B) INCORRECT:

A reactive nonstress test provides a snapshot of fetal well-being but does not address ongoing concerns of intrauterine growth restriction and decreased fetal movements. Deferring sonography until 36 weeks overlooks the need for serial assessments to monitor fetal growth and amniotic fluid volume, which are essential in managing potential placental insufficiency.

C) CORRECT:

Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) is indicated by a fetus below the 10th percentile for gestational age. Serial ultrasound assessments are crucial for monitoring fetal growth, amniotic fluid volume, and placental function. Doppler flow studies provide insights into fetal hemodynamics, particularly in the umbilical artery. Abnormal Doppler findings, such as absent or reversed end-diastolic flow, suggest placental insufficiency and guide intervention timing. Maternal smoking exacerbates placental dysfunction, necessitating vigilant monitoring to prevent adverse fetal outcomes.

Key learning point: Serial ultrasound is the most valuable diagnostic tool for assessing intrauterine growth restriction as it allows for detailed evaluation of fetal growth, amniotic fluid, and Doppler studies.

D) INCORRECT:

Low-dose aspirin is effective when started early in pregnancy for preeclampsia prevention, not as a treatment for established fetal growth restriction at 30 weeks. The patient lacks risk factors for preeclampsia, and aspirin initiation at this stage is unlikely to benefit placental function.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks of gestation presents to the Delivery Room in active labor. She has regular contractions, and her cervix is dilated to 6 cm. The fetal heart trace shows absent variability and recurrent late decelerations despite maternal repositioning and adequate hydration. The fetal station is -1.
What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Administration of supplemental oxygen to the mother
Continuation of current management and reevaluation

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Supplemental oxygen is considered when maternal hypoxemia is present. In this case, the issue is uteroplacental insufficiency, not maternal oxygenation. Studies show no significant neonatal outcome improvement with routine maternal oxygen supplementation in such cases, as impaired placental blood flow limits fetal oxygen transfer.

B) INCORRECT:

An intrauterine pressure catheter assesses contraction strength, useful in cases of suspected uterine hypotony or tachysystole. This patient has regular contractions and is 6 cm dilated, indicating adequate uterine activity. The fetal heart rate pattern suggests uteroplacental insufficiency, not contraction issues. Therefore, measuring contraction strength would not alter management.

C) INCORRECT:

Persistent absent variability and recurrent late decelerations indicate ongoing fetal compromise despite maternal repositioning and hydration. With 6 cm cervical dilation and a fetal station of -1, vaginal delivery is not imminent. Continued observation risks worsening fetal acidemia, as the fetus is not tolerating labor well.

D) CORRECT:

Absent variability in fetal heart rate monitoring indicates impaired fetal autonomic function, often due to hypoxic injury. Recurrent late decelerations suggest uteroplacental insufficiency, leading to transient fetal hypoxia. Despite maternal repositioning and hydration, these patterns persist, indicating significant risk for fetal acidemia. At 39 weeks of gestation, with 6 cm cervical dilation and a fetal station of -1, timely vaginal delivery is unlikely. An emergency cesarean delivery is warranted to ensure fetal well-being.

Key learning point: In the presence of fetal distress indicated by absent variability and recurrent late decelerations on CTG, an emergency cesarean section is warranted to prevent fetal hypoxia and potential complications.

questions.text: You are seeing a 38-year-old woman, gravida 1, at 33 weeks' gestation for a routine prenatal visit. She reports feeling well and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated so far. She has attended all previous routine prenatal visits. Her medical history includes pregestational hypertension. Her current medications are methyldopa, low-dose aspirin, and a prenatal multivitamin. She previously smoked 5 cigarettes daily for 15 years but quit when she became pregnant. Her temperature is 36.7°C, pulse is 80/min, respirations are 16/min, and blood pressure is 146/94 mm Hg. On examination, her fundal height is 27 cm. Fetal heart rate is 145/min. The remainder of the examination is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Betamethasone therapy and induction of labor.

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

In pregnant women with suspected IUGR, transabdominal or transvaginal fetal ultrasonography is indicated for an accurate assessment of pregnancy dating and fetal abnormalities. The diagnosis of IUGR is confirmed by an estimated fetal weight or a fetal abdominal circumference below the 10th percentile. Chronic hypertension, which this patient has, is a risk factor for IUGR because it can lead to placental insufficiency, with a consequent decrease in blood flow and oxygen delivery to the fetus. Other risk factors for this condition include maternal substance abuse (e.g., alcohol, cocaine), teratogen exposure (e.g., carbamazepine, warfarin), multiple gestations, placenta previa, fetal genetic abnormalities, and intrauterine infections. Management includes treatment of the underlying cause (e.g., blood pressure control in this patient) and outpatient monitoring.

Key learning point: Suspected intrauterine growth restriction should be evaluated with fetal ultrasonography to confirm the diagnosis and assess fetal well-being.

B) INCORRECT:

Reassurance and follow-up in 2 weeks would be indicated if this patient's examination showed no abnormalities. However, the discrepancy between fundal height and gestational age suggests IUGR, which requires further evaluation.

C) INCORRECT:

A contraction stress test can be used for fetal evaluation in patients with severe or complicated IUGR (e.g., fetal weight < 5th percentile, oligohydramnios, preeclampsia, decelerating growth velocity, increasing umbilical Doppler index) and a nonreactive nonstress test. Although IUGR is suspected in this patient, the diagnosis needs to be confirmed before a contraction stress test is considered.

D) INCORRECT:

Betamethasone therapy and induction of labor are indicated in patients at < 34 weeks' gestation if preterm delivery, for which IUGR is a risk factor, is anticipated. Although IUGR is suspected in this patient, the diagnosis needs to be confirmed first. In addition, there are no signs of, or indications for, preterm labor at this time.

E) INCORRECT:

A glucose challenge test should be performed in all pregnant women between 24 and 28 weeks' gestation as part of the screening for gestational diabetes mellitus, which is a risk factor for IUGR. Since this patient is at 33 weeks' gestation and has attended all previous prenatal visits, a glucose challenge test has most likely already been performed. A different step is indicated at this time.
questions.hint: Between 24 and 36 weeks' gestation, the fundal height (in cm) should roughly equal the gestational age (in weeks). A fundal height of at least 3 cm less than the gestational age, as seen here, should raise concern for intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

questions.text:
A 31-year-old G2P1 woman at 39 weeks of gestation is in active labor for 4 hours. An ultrasound 2 weeks ago suggested fetal growth restriction with an estimated fetal weight below the 5th percentile. She has regular contractions, and the fetus is in a vertex presentation. Fetal heart rate tracings are reassuring, and her vital signs are normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous oxytocin is used for inadequate uterine activity or protraction disorders. This patient has regular contractions and reassuring fetal heart rate tracings, indicating appropriate labor progression. There is no evidence of uterine inertia or need for contraction augmentation.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate cesarean delivery is reserved for nonreassuring fetal heart rate patterns or signs of acute distress. This patient has reassuring fetal heart tracings and stable maternal vitals, indicating the fetus is tolerating labor well. Cesarean delivery is not warranted based on historical ultrasound findings alone.

C) CORRECT:

In a patient with fetal growth restriction but reassuring fetal heart rate tracings and stable maternal vitals, expectant management during labor is appropriate. The absence of fetal distress or abnormal labor progression supports allowing labor to proceed naturally towards vaginal delivery. A vertex presentation with regular contractions indicates proper labor progression. Continuous monitoring of maternal and fetal parameters ensures prompt response to any changes in fetal well-being or maternal status. Fetal growth restriction alone does not necessitate immediate intervention without signs of distress.

Key learning point: In the absence of fetal distress or other complications, a spontaneous vaginal delivery is appropriate for a patient in active labor with a vertex presentation, even in the presence of intrauterine growth restriction.

D) INCORRECT:

Vacuum-assisted delivery is indicated for maternal exhaustion, prolonged second stage, or nonreassuring fetal status. This patient has reassuring fetal heart rate tracings and no signs of fetal or maternal compromise, making vacuum assistance unnecessary.
